results.title: CRISPR Gene Editing Revolution: How Biotechnology Advances Are...
results.content: The scientific world experienced a watershed moment in late 2023 when the U.S. FDA approved Casgevy, the first CRISPR gene therapy to treat patients with sickle cell disease and beta-thalassemia. For the first time in human history, a therapy powered by CRISPR gene editing transformed a chronic genetic disorder into a treatable, and potentially curable, condition. Unlike earlier gene-editing technologies that required designing custom DNA-cutting enzymes for each target sequence, CRISPR works with a guide RNA and a protein called Cas9. Beyond blood disorders, CRISPR gene editing addresses rare genetic conditions previously considered hopeless. CRISPR-edited CAR-T cell therapies for cancer eliminate checkpoint inhibitors that allow tumors to evade immune detection, potentially extending survival in patients with otherwise resistant cancers. In-vivo CRISPR therapies, those administered directly to patients rather than editing cells in the laboratory, are under investigation for transthyretin amyloidosis, a protein-misfolding disease affecting the heart and nerves. As CRISPR gene editing matures, the fundamental nature of medical practice may shift from chronic disease management to genetic correction at the source.

results.title: Gene Editing CRISPR : Techniques & Sickle Cell | Vaia
results.content: CRISPR gene editing has potential applications in medicine, including the treatment of genetic disorders , cancer therapies , and the development of personalized medicine. It can be used to correct mutations, enhance immune responses, and potentially eliminate viral infections.
